item.title: Rachel Reeves Counters Cuts Narrative With UK Building Blitz
item.description: Chancellor of the Exchequer Rachel Reeves will detail hundreds of billions of pounds of investment in projects to fix Britain’s creaking infrastructure during next week’s spending review, a crunch moment for Keir Starmer’s administration as it struggles to regain momentum after a faltering first year in power.
item.dc:creator: Joe Mayes, Ailbhe Rea

media:content.media:description: UK Chancellor of the Exchequer Rachel Reeves.

item.title: Malaysia Court Rejects Anwar’s Bid to Pause Sex Assault Suit
item.description: Malaysia’s High Court rejected Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim’s bid to pause a civil suit by his former aide, who accused the leader of committing sexual assault in 2018.
item.dc:creator: Kok Leong Chan, Anisah Shukry

media:content.media:description: Anwar Ibrahim Photographer: Ore Huiying/Bloomberg

item.title: South Korea’s Lee Charts New Path in Diplomacy
item.description: Welcome to Balance of Power, bringing you the latest in global politics. If you haven’t yet, sign up here.
item.dc:creator: Jasmine Ng

media:content.media:description: Lee Jae-myung, presidential candidate for the Democratic Party, left, and his wife Kim Hye-gyeong at the party's election night event in Seoul, South Korea, on Wednesday, June 4, 2025. With almost 95% of the ballots counted, Lee, a left-leaning former labor activist, had won 48.8% of the vote while the ruling People Power Party’s candidate Kim Moon-soo had 42.0%, according the National Election Commission, a narrower margin than indicated by an earlier exit poll. Photographer: SeongJoon Cho/Bloomberg

item.title: Israel Defense Exports Hit Record in 2024 as Europe Demand Jumps
item.description: Israel’s defense exports hit a record for a fourth consecutive year thanks largely to growing demand from Europe, even as some of its nations call for sanctions over the war in Gaza.
item.dc:creator: Galit Altstein

media:content.media:description: A Hermes 900 medium-altitude, long-endurance unmanned aerial vehicle at the Elbit Systems Ltd. stand at the International Defence and Security Technologies Fair in Brno, Czech Republic, on May 28. Photographer: Milan Jaros/Bloomberg

item.title: UK Minister Rules Out Full Reversal of Winter Fuel Payment Cuts
item.description: The UK government has ruled out fully reversing the £1.8 billion cut to winter fuel payments for pensioners announced last year but does plan to “make more pensioners eligible,” Pensions Minister Torsten Bell told parliament on Wednesday.
item.dc:creator: Philip Aldrick

media:content.media:description: A domestic radiator thermostat.

item.title: Outspoken South Korea Leftist Survived Stabbing on Path to Power
item.description: Lee Jae-myung, the tenacious left-leaning maverick who became South Korea’s new president on Wednesday, has spent a lifetime picking himself off the canvas to fight again.
item.dc:creator: Soo-Hyang Choi

media:content.media:description: Lee Jae-myung, center left, and his wife Kim Hye-gyeong at the party’s election night event in Seoul on June 4.

item.title: Germany Backs €46 Billion in Corporate Tax Breaks to Spur Growth
item.description: Germany’s cabinet approved a package of tax breaks for companies worth an estimated €46 billion ($52 billion), part of a broader push to revive an economy that’s forecast to stagnate for a third straight year in 2025.
item.dc:creator: Kamil Kowalcze

media:content.media:description: Lars Klingbeil, right, and Friedrich Merz during a cabinet meeting in Berlin, on May 14.

item.title: Dutch Premier Warns of Lawmaking Delays After Coalition Collapse
item.description: Dutch caretaker Prime Minister Dick Schoof told lawmakers they need to decide which issues to prioritize, but admitted that delays will be inevitable following the collapse of his government.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Van Oosterom, Sarah Jacob

media:content.media:description: Dutch caretaker Prime Minister Dick Schoof in The Hague on June 4.

item.title: Trump Obscures Medicaid Cuts in Bid to Pass Massive Tax Bill
item.description: Donald Trump publicly resisted Medicaid cuts — until his budget director, Russell Vought, convinced the president that reductions to heath coverage for low-income people, embedded in the Republican tax bill, were just weeding out fraud and abuse.
item.dc:creator: Nancy Cook

media:content.media:description: Russell Vought,

item.title: Ex-Credit Suisse Boss Is Barred From Running in Ivorian Vote
item.description: Ivory Coast’s electoral commission excluded former Credit Suisse AG Chief Executive Officer Tidjane Thiam from the country’s voters’ roll, closing off his bid to run for president this year.
item.dc:creator: Kamailoudini Tagba

media:content.media:description: Tidjane Thiam Photographer: Marco Bello/Bloomberg

item.title: Elon Musk Blasts Trump Tax Bill as Budget-Busting ‘Abomination’
item.description: Donald Trump ally Elon Musk lambasted the president’s signature tax bill as a budget-busting “abomination” as Republican fiscal hawks stepped up criticism of the massive fiscal package.
item.dc:creator: Erik Wasson, Maeve Sheehey

media:content.media:description: Senator Rand Paul

item.title: Lagarde’s ECB Future Set for Scrutiny After WEF Job Speculation
item.description: Christine Lagarde is about to face scrutiny on her commitment to keep leading the European Central Bank, not least as she nears the milestone of having just about tamed inflation.
item.dc:creator: Jana Randow, Craig Stirling

media:content.media:description: Christine Lagarde Photographer: Krisztian Bocsi/Bloomberg

item.title: Rubio Eulogizes Tiananmen Protesters as Tariffs Test Ties
item.description: US Secretary of State Marco Rubio praised pro-democracy protesters who were killed in Beijing’s bloody Tiananmen Square crackdown 36 years ago, carrying on Washington’s criticism of China’s human rights record as tariff disputes further test already frayed ties.
item.dc:creator: Alan Wong

media:content.media:description: Marco Rubio Photographer: Nathan Howard/Bloomberg

item.title: Trump Says China’s Xi Is ‘Extremely Hard to Make a Deal With’
item.description: President Donald Trump said in a late-night social media post that Chinese leader Xi Jinping was very tough to make a deal with, raising questions about whether a fragile economic truce between the world’s two largest economies will hold.
item.dc:creator: Josh Xiao

media:content.media:description: Donald Trump and Xi Jinping in 2017. Photographer: Nicolas Asfouri/AFP/Getty Images

item.title: Iran’s Khamenei Spurns ‘Arrogant’ US Nuclear-Deal Proposal
item.description: Iran’s Supreme Leader Ayatollah Ali Khamenei criticized a US proposal for a nuclear deal and called American officials “arrogant” for expecting the Islamic Republic to cease uranium enrichment.
item.dc:creator: Arsalan Shahla

media:content.media:description: Ayatollah Ali Khamenei Photographer: Majid Saeedi/Getty Images

item.title: South Korean Stocks Enter Bull Market, Bonds Sink After Election
item.description: South Korea’s equity benchmark climbed to enter a bull market, after Lee Jae-myung’s widely-expected win in the presidential election ended a months-long political leadership vacuum.
item.dc:creator: Youkyung Lee, Jaehyun Eom

item.title: Trump Gives UK Five-Week Deadline After Reprieve on Steel Tariff
item.description: The UK is contending with a new five-week deadline to finalize its trade agreement with the US after President Donald Trump spared the country’s steel and aluminum exports from a doubling of existing tariffs.
item.dc:creator: Julian Harris

media:content.media:description: A worker prepares to wrap cold drawn stainless steel bars at a factory in Sheffield. Photographer: Dominic Lipinski/Bloomberg

item.title: Korean Air Chairman Calls for Stability, Tariff Cuts
item.description: South Korea’s next government should prioritize making a trade deal with Washington that shields the aviation industry from tariffs, the head of the country’s largest airline said.
item.dc:creator: Danny Lee, Guy Johnson

media:content.media:description: Cho Won-Tae Photographer: Anindito Mukherjee/Bloomberg

item.title: New South Korean President Faces Tariff, North Korea Threats
item.description: South Korea’s newly elected President Lee Jae-myung took office with a pledge to revive a national economy threatened by Donald Trump’s tariffs just as the US president doubled duties on steel and aluminum, highlighting the pressing challenges facing the Asian leader.
item.dc:creator: Soo-Hyang Choi, Hyonhee Shin

media:content.media:description: Lee Jae-myung at the National Assembly in Seoul on June 4.

item.title: Democrats Lose Challenge to Trump’s Order on Election Commission
item.description: The Democratic Party’s governing body lost its legal challenge to an executive order by President Donald Trump that it said would eliminate the bipartisan nature of the Federal Elections Commission and shift authority to the White House.
item.dc:creator: Robert Burnson

item.title: Trump Signs Order Doubling US Steel, Aluminum Tariffs to 50%
item.description: President Donald Trump has raised steel and aluminum tariffs to 50% from 25%, following through on a pledge to boost US import taxes to help domestic manufacturers.
item.dc:creator: Josh Wingrove

media:content.media:description: A crane moves a roll of coiled steel at a steel plant in Hamilton, Ontario. Photographer: James MacDonald/Bloomberg

item.title: Merz Has Courted and Criticized Trump From Afar. Now They Meet
item.description: After weeks of preparation, the new German chancellor faces his biggest test yet.
item.dc:creator: Arne Delfs

media:content.media:description: Friedrich Merz will travel to Washington for his inaugural meeting with Trump on June 5.

item.title: UK Confronts Hard Reality of Rebuilding Its Military Prowess
item.description: Years of underinvestment, botched contracts and poor recruitment have hollowed out what was once a superpower.
item.dc:creator: Ellen Milligan, Caroline Hepker

media:content.media:description: The factory floor at BAE System’s manufacturing site in Washington, northeast England.

item.title: Pentagon Wants to Delay Navy’s Next-Gen Fighter to Focus on F-47
item.description: The Pentagon wants to give priority to the Air Force’s F-47 stealth fighter over Navy plans to develop its own next-generation jet, arguing that pursuing the two programs at the same time could delay them both.
item.dc:creator: Anthony Capaccio

media:content.media:description: A rendering of Air Force's sixth-generation fighter, the F-47. Source: US Air Force

item.title: Philippine Vice President Duterte Questions Impeachment Trial Under New Congress
item.description: Philippine Vice President Sara Duterte has questioned whether her impeachment trial on charges that include a suspected plot to assassinate President Ferdinand Marcos Jr. can go forward when a new set of lawmakers takes office next month.
item.dc:creator: Andreo Calonzo, Cliff Harvey Venzon

media:content.media:description: Sara Duterte Photographer: Lisa Marie David/Bloomberg

item.title: University of Florida President Pick Santa Ono Rejected After Republican DEI Backlash
item.description: Florida state university leaders voted to reject Santo Ono as president of the University of Florida, following Republican backlash over the former University of Michigan president’s previous support for diversity programs.
item.dc:creator: Janet Lorin, Michael Smith

media:content.media:description: Gainesville, University of Florida, campus entrance with students. (Photo by: Jeffrey Greenberg/Universal Images Group via Getty Images)

item.title: Mexico Will Ask US Government for Steel Tariff Exemption
item.description: Mexico will ask Donald Trump’s administration this week to be exempted from an increase in steel tariffs to 50%, the country’s economy minister said on Tuesday.
item.dc:creator: Alex Vasquez

media:content.media:description: View of a truck loaded with steel rolls in the Lazaro Cardenas Cargo Port, Michoacan State, Mexico on April 25, 2025. (Photo by Alfredo ESTRELLA / AFP) (Photo by ALFREDO ESTRELLA/AFP via Getty Images) Photographer: ALFREDO ESTRELLA/AFP

item.title: South Korea Elects Lee President, Capping Six Months of Chaos
item.description: Left-leaning challenger Lee Jae-myung won South Korea’s presidential election, ending three years of conservative rule in a race that was largely a verdict on his ousted predecessor’s botched attempt to revive martial law in the longstanding US ally.
item.dc:creator: Soo-Hyang Choi, Hyonhee Shin

media:content.media:description: Lee Jae-myung on June 4. Photographer: SeongJoon Cho/Bloomberg

item.title: Trump Taps Former Small Business Chief for Role Overseeing CFIUS
item.description: President Donald Trump has nominated Chris Pilkerton, the acting head of the Small Business Administration during his first term, to oversee a committee charged with screening foreign investments into the US as well as outbound investments in foreign countries, with a close eye on competition with China.
item.dc:creator: Daniel Flatley

media:content.media:description: The US Treasury Department building in Washington, DC, US, on Saturday, May 10, 2025. The legislative push for President Donald Trump's massive tax package will begin in earnest next week as key House committees consider the legislation despite lingering divisions among Republicans. Photographer: Aaron Schwartz/Bloomberg

item.title: House SALT Deal Will Have to Change, Senate Leader Thune Says
item.description: Senate Majority Leader John Thune believes the deal that led the US House to increase the maximum deduction for state and local taxes to $40,000 will have to be changed in his chamber, according to his office.
item.dc:creator: Steven T. Dennis, John Harney

media:content.media:description: Senate Majority Leader John Thune at the US Capitol in Washington, DC, on June 3.
